abstractContent.text: This paper offers a provisional mathematical typology of metrical representations.
First, a family of algebras corresponding to different versions of grid and bracketed grid theory is introduced.
It is subsequently shown in what way bracketed grid theory differs from metrical theories using trees.

Finally, we show that there are no significant differences between the formalism of bracketed grids (for metrical structure) and the representation used in the work of [Kaye, et al., 1985], [1990] for subsyllabic structure.

introductionContent.text: The most well-known characteristic of Non-linear Phonology is that it shifted its attention from the theory of rules (like in) to the theory of representations.
During the last decade phonologists have developed a theory of representations that is sufficiently rich and adequate to describe a wide range of facts from the phonologies of various languages.
It is a fairly recent development that these representations are being studied also from a purely formal point of view.
There has been done some work on autosegmental structure (for instance) and also some work on metrical trees (like in unification phonology and in categorial logics).

As far as I know, apart from the pioneering work by, hitherto no attention has been paid to the formal aspects of the most popular framework of metrical phonolog~y nowadays, the bracketed grids framework.
Yet a lot of questions have to be answered with regard to bracketed grids.
First of all, some authors (for instance) have expressed the intuition that bracketed grids and tree structures (e.g. the labeled trees of and related work) are equivalent.
In this paper, I study this intuition in some formal detail and show that it is wrong.
Secondly, one can wonder what the exact relation is between higher-order metrical structure (foot, word) and subsyllabic structure.
In this paper I will show that apart from a fewempirically unimportant details, bracketed grids are equivalent to the kind of subsyllabic structure that is advocated by , t.
The definition of a bracketed grid Below I give a formal definition of the bracketed grid, as it is introduced by HV and subsequently elaborated and revised by these authors and others, most notably.
HV have a major part of their book devoted to the formalism themselves, but there are numerous problems with this formalization.
I will mention two of them.
First, their formalization is not flexible enough to capture all instances of (bracketed) grid theory as it is actually used in the literature of the last few years.
They merely give a sketch of the specific implementation of bracketed grid theory as it is used in the rest of their book.

Secondly, their way of formalizing bracketing grids has very much a 'derivational' flavour.
They are more interested in how grids can be built than in what they look like.
Although looking at the derivational aspects is an interesting and worthwile enterprise in itself, it makes their formalism less suitable fora comparison with metrical trees.
